summary: Slikey, re: prioritizing players vs modders
mainText:
'We are really prioritizing both and we don't pretend to have an answer right now. We believe that things like Patreon have really low click-thru rates, so the first logical step would be to bring the mods together with that voluntary support and bring the barrier to support down. We may even find other ways to even directly benefit from supporting a modders. 
There are many oppurtunities that haven't been explored yet and I am optimistic that we can keep the modding ecosystem accessible and still bring more revenue to modders. We will try our best to innovate here and stay on top of feedback.'

summary: Simon, re: InTheLittleWood wondering if capes are rigid or have physics
mainText: 'Capes have animations!'

summary: Paris, re: user's cottagecore Hytale avatar
mainText: 'This is soooooooooooo pretty üò≠'

summary: Slikey talks approaches to modding
mainText:
'We are not controlling the modding space and distribution. So at launch, there can't really be a walled garden. I think especially initially it won't be a problem as everyone is still learning and working together. 

We have talked a lot with modders over the past few weeks and there seems to be a sentiment that there are 2 approaches to mods: (1) Mod Assets and (2) Mods for Players. 

(1) Is basically an asset marketplace like http://Fab.com etc. This is pretty much entirely outside of our control and we don't have any plans around that at the moment.
(2) Mods for Players generally have multiple options aswell. There are (I) Free Mods, (II) Donation / Humble Bundle / Itch, (III) Freemium Mods, (IV) Paid Mods and (V) Closed Mods.

I. Free Mods generally have the highest level of acceptance and most vibrant ecosystems. The majority of modders prefer their mods to be free but they also would like a future where they can pay themselves and potentially expand to a team. These mods are often supported by platforms like CurseForge through Ads / Premium subscriptions.

II. Donation / Humble Bundle / Itch have a "Pay what you want" approach and generally well done mods show good revenue data - especially if players are prompted and the creator behind it is transparent with the funds. Some modders offer a patreon to emulate this model. This also doesn't have the drawback of a walled garden and high acceptance. Sadly there is also no "security" in here.

III. Freemium Mods can offer the base mod but accept payment for certain benefits. One example here would be Optifine where you could purchase an Optifine cape. This provides an adventage and generally the Optifine cape seemed to be well accepted in the community. 

IV. Paid Mods are generally a more "safe" income approach for modders, especially when they are putting significant upfront effort into it but they are really inaccessible and turn a mod browser into a shopping mall. Feedback from players is extremely negative while that obviously depends on the platform - PC players is much more negative about them due to mods being traditionally free. Additionally it results in modding piracy.

V. Closed Mods are usually done by server networks. Hypixel Network uses server-side software to modify the server software to offer their own gameplay experience which allows various avenues for monetization. e.g. a World of Tanks minigame which would unlock new cosmetics for your tank and beyond. I think closed mods / running a server network is most "stable" income source but also has all the trouble of running a GaaS environment with all the positives and negatives.

Our initial approach is a "Wild West". We are internally not a fan of the inaccessibility of shopping mall modding which strongly associates mods with money. We don't have a solid strategy yet and when we bring modding into the game itself, we'd probably try to make the (II.) approach our first shot while finding a way to passively support creators using our creator program. We are also open to other strategies that strike this find balance of "accessible but rewarding" in a way that results in a great experience for everyone.'

summary: Simon, re: user saying why not due closed beta
mainText:
'I bought the game IP only 3 weeks ago, and promised to release it ASAP. I poured a lot of money into saving this game and will continue to do so. I care about it and want the community involved, making mods / servers and have fun with us.

If you knew my story, you would understand, but from an outsider, you might not, and that's ok.

You can read more here:
https://hytale.com/news/2025/11/hytale-is-saved'

summary: Lyall, re: updating FAQ
mainText:
'After some misinterpretation yesterday, Simon went ahead to update one of the answers I gave.
Sorry for not being clear enough with my wording and for causing confusion within the community.

Wish I could say this is going to be the last time but as a non-native speaker simple errors might happen.

You are always free to ask clarifying questions in cases of uncertainty - if I'm able to answer them, I will.'

summary: Simon, re: French user saying it's too late to change the answer
mainText:
'Je vais attendre ton review avec impatience üòÖ'

(Translation: I'm looking forward to your review üòÖ)

summary: Simon, re: answer to Steam release in FAQ
mainText:
'I updated Patrick‚Äôs answer about Steam on the blog. The wording around ‚Äúover-indexing ‚Äù was confusing and misinterpreted by many, making it sound like we were avoiding Steam because of negative reviews. 
If you‚Äôve been reading my posts on X lately, you know very well I‚Äôve been brutally honest about the state of the game. It would be pretty out of place for us to suddenly avoid Steam for doing the same! 

We‚Äôre both non-native English speakers, so that's on us for not being clear with the wording. I rewrote it to reflect better what we actually meant to say.

Didn't expect millions of views, posts and articles about this in the past few hours, thanks for the free advertising thoughüòÖ'

summary: Simon, re: Steam vs Hytale features
mainText:
'Yeah, the Steam workshop doesn't support many of the features we would like to see. Also, if you type Hytale on Steam, you see Hitler games, I mean, what? The over-indexing negative review was just an easier point to explain than getting into the full details. Negative reviews are the most important ones to me; that's all I've been reading from our testers in the past two weeks. 

I think that should have been the main point of the blog post, but it is what it is. Now we see that people are REALLY passionate about Steam, almost to the extreme. I also don't really buy games outside of Steam, so I get the hate.

However, the best-selling game of all time is not on Steam.'

summary: Simon, re: user showing cool concept art
mainText: 'Sent to the level designer, cool stuff!'

summary: Simon, re: user saying Steam's features don't help with playing the game
mainText:
'In fact, some features we want to do are not yet possible on Steam, so we would need to cut some features to go on Steam. 

We will be contacting Steam after launch to see what's possible. But I suspect we are a small fish in the pond.'

summary: Simon, re: user saying he as the owner should determine if his game is worthy
mainText:
'For some context, I left the game studio about 5+ years ago and repurchased it only a few weeks ago.

I'm betting many $ millions on it. I don't care about ROI; I want to release a game and have fun with it.'

(Re: getting investors instead of customers)

summary: Simon, re: user asking why they'd bother putting it on consoles in a bad state
mainText:
'It won't be on consoles for a while; it's only "planned".
We don't even support controllers yet.
We are PC gamers, and the game is built for PC first.
Will explore consoles later.'

summary: Simon, re: user suggesting going for investors instead of selling to players in a bad state
mainText:
'Hytale needs to be in players' hands, not investors'.
Players will decide if it's worthy.'

summary: Simon, re: user saying Simon's trying to bait and drive up sales
mainText:
'If I wanted to drive up sales I would put it up on Steam and hype the game. I'm doing the exact opposite.
There will be warnings when you buy.
This is going to be a long journey.'

summary: Simon, re: blog explaining history
mainText: 'Yeah, that blog post explains the situation.'

A lot to go through.'

summary: Simon, re: user saying 'the game is bad, yet you want money for it'

I'm already supporting a team of 40+ people with my personal money and can continue to do so for many years.
Watch videos about the situation if you want to learn more about me buying back the game from Riot.'

summary: Simon, re: lore drawing community to Hytale
mainText:
'The lore you theorized for years is different from the lore I have seen. 

This is why we need a pause, and see what‚Äôs going on.

Will figure out post launch!'

summary: Simon, re: watching CanadianFlash for lore
mainText: 'I think I will to understand what the public think the lore is versus what the documents actually shows üòÖ'

summary: Simon, re: Gaia
mainText:
'Gaia is going to be central to the lore, even in early access! 
I was walking around in her temple today, just to give you some context üòÖ

Varyn will also be part of the lore later on. üëÄ'

summary: Simon, re: why lore needs to be looked at
mainText:
'I personally don‚Äôt have time to read all of the lore written in the past decade about a game that had no gameplay given that we release in 40 days.
There are 2 very different lore path conflicting with each other in the documents. 

Ultimately, don‚Äôt want the lore to block us from making a great game.

Of course will use the lore to enhance the game as we go. Already doing so.

We will be hiring writers and lore wizards after early access launch. Salvage as much as we can. 

We have a ‚Äúback to basics‚Äù lore template at the moment, using what was done many years ago, inspired from some concept shown.  Building a strong foundation.'

summary: Simon, re: lore
mainText: 'The general lore will stay relatively the same, however some more specific things will undergo review, especially the non public one.'

summary: Simon, re: lore "reset"
mainText: 'Hitting reset button doesn‚Äôt mean deleting everything. It just means we have to spend time making sure it makes sense going forward. I have seen some things I do not agree with, which means a complete review is required.'

summary: Simon, re: Hytale's Lore
mainText:
'FYI, to set expectations: all lore is reset and/or on hold for review.
All concepts art are outdated as well.
Like the whole feran/scarak lore mentioned in the video is under review.

Everything was just concepts. Lots of documentation, none of it in-game. 

So please don‚Äôt ready too much into hints, you will be disappointed.

The whole cursebreaker arc allows us to reset and have a starting point.'

summary: Lyall, re: localization
mainText:
'There won't be any localization of Hytale at early access, but thanks to our smart engineers, everything is already built with localization in mind. 
This means we'll be able to deliver localized versions of the game at a later stage without having to make big code changes.'

summary: Simon, re: official merch keeping % low
mainText: 'Merch and cosmetics would help us keep the % low, or even keep it at 0% for sure. We are not planning to grow the team into a big behemoth, so the less management we have to do, the better.'

summary: Lyall, re: asking questions
mainText: 'You are always free to ask more questions. I'm sure we can make a part 2 in due time.'

summary: Lyall, re: payment methods
mainText: 'Yes, Pix should be available as a payment method for Brazil.'

summary: Simon, re: what Hytale could provide
mainText:
'If we ever take a %, you can be sure we would provide you more players and assets/code to make it worth more than we take.
As I said, ideally close to 0% for such servers!'

summary: Simon, re: taking % of server's money
mainText:
'The difference is, we would provide something in return! Also 20% is on the far end of the maximum.
Ideally we stick close to 0% for self hosted servers. I would rather avoid micromanaging and let people do their own things.'

summary: Simon, re: server owners using marketplace
mainText:
'There is no marketplace; you use your own stores.
At least that's the plan for early access.
We do not want to micro-manage server owners, but that also means you need to offer customer support and other services to your players!'
